posts.name: Kerem Alper Batal
posts.cooked:
Hi everyone,

I want to do an alignment with using photonvision but not just aiming to apriltag with turning the robot. I want to move my robot right in front of the apriltag, like apriltag and my robot will be facing.

apriltagAlignment 1178×520 69.3 KB

apriltagAlignment 1178×520 69.3 KB

apriltagAlignment 1178×520 69.3 KB

This picture shows that what i want. Every possible pose (that camera can see the apriltag) should be able to make this happen.

I thought of a method for this, robot wil turn due to tx(Yaw) data and will move sideway due to Skew data. But there is a problem. I have worked with Limelight before and with limelight i could get the Skew data. But i saw a note on Photonvision docs that says i can not get the skew data with apriltags.

Screenshot_14 720×840 44.1 KB

Screenshot_14 720×840 44.1 KB

Screenshot_14 720×840 44.1 KB

I tried getting it but it returns just 0. So it did not work.

Is there something I don’t know? or what other method can I use?(expect odometry because ı dont trust the odometry right now)

Note: I am working on Sim right now.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
kab:

I thought of a method for this, robot wil turn due to tx(Yaw) data and will move sideway due to Skew data.

I think this would generally be backward. Skew is a product of not having the camera pointed straight-on at the target - IE, you want to change robot yaw until skew reads zero. Once pointed at the same yaw as the target, moving sideways until the tag is centered image would yield alignment.

That being said, most I’ve worked with have gone down the path of solving this with 3d data. After calibrating the camera, the camera will produce Transform3d() objects which indicate where the target is at, relative to the camera. By projecting this onto the ground, and providing drivetrain commands that drive the transform to a desired position relative to the tag (say, 1 foot back, aligned in yaw, and 0 ft side to side), you can achieve the same alignment.

I’m not entirely sure how well skew itself would work in this case, due to needing fairly high gains between the skew measurement (which will be noisy) and the drivetrain commands.

Additionally, note all these methods do not have latency compensation - you’ll need to make sure your pipeline is running with fairly low latency. Any latency just limits how aggressive your control gains to the drivetrain can be.  I’d spitball <100ms, but your mileage may vary.

posts.name: Kerem Alper Batal
posts.cooked:
First of all thanks for your reply.

gerthworm:

you want to change robot yaw until skew reads zero. Once pointed at the same yaw as the target, moving sideways until the tag is centered image would yield alignment.

Actually my plan is changing robot yaw until tx(getYaw) reads zero and while doing this, moving robot sideways until skew reads zero.

gerthworm:

That being said, most I’ve worked with have gone down the path of solving this with 3d data. After calibrating the camera, the camera will produce Transform3d() objects which indicate where the target is at, relative to the camera. By projecting this onto the ground, and providing drivetrain commands that drive the transform to a desired position relative to the tag (say, 1 foot back, aligned in yaw, and 0 ft side to side), you can achieve the same alignment.

Yeah i know the best way to use poses and transforms but i dont want to use odometry and do a path to a pose because i dont trust our odomerty right now and also i dont know much about getting Transform3d() object and how to use it. And use a simple method for this alignment.

I asked it to ChatGPT and it said, i can calculate my own skew in degrees using getCorners method of Photonvision. Basically i can calculate the skew data using difference between corners of target. I will try that.

posts.name: BobbyVanNess
posts.cooked:
Why don’t you trust odometry? Teams run some pretty complex autos with just odometry, ours included. The accumulated error is small, like less than an inch over 10 feet. If odometry isn’t working reliably, then check that your motors, gear ratios, wheel diameters, gyro direction etc are all set up properly in code.

Using photonvision and odometry to feed the robot’s pose estimate is generally very robust. Then you can autonomously drive to a specific spot rather than trying to get to some inferred position from the tag.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
If you can use your gyro to rotate to the correct angle based on the tag ID (in multiples of 60 degrees) with a P loop, then you can use vision to just strafe towards the target in robot-centric fashion. It’s much easier to center a tag via PID on the tx than it is to extract yaw info from the tag, especially head-on, due to tag ambiguity.

Once you’re centered on the tag and pushed up against the reef, you can use your now-known position to set your odometry for the next path towards the HP station (in auto). If you want to offset yourself to the left or right of the tag, just tweak the target tx to be offset from 0. For HP loading you can use the exact same strategy.

If you’re not super familiar with full 3D localization with tags, I think the above method will prove to be simple and reliable.

posts.name: Kerem Alper Batal
posts.cooked: Thanks for the reply. I thought about that method too before. That was my second plan; I will use it if the skew method does not work. I don’t know why, but the skew method feels more accurate. But your method will work too, I guess.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: If you’re facing the tag and the camera view is parallel to it, you will have ambiguity issues in 3d mode that makes the yaw from the camera jump around. If you’re using a modern gyro, it will be more stable. I don’t know if you can differentiate yaw and skew in 2d mode, though it might be possible using the raw detected corner locations.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Hmmm. Multiple things in this post contradict advice on best-practices.

But, it seems you have a pretty clear idea of what you want to do.

While I don’t agree with your assessment of what is easy and hard, it’s ultimately your responsibility to forge a path for your team.

I wish you luck and learning!
